div.p: Global element for recording stretches of time; can be used everywhere where it is possible to type text (paragraphs, CHRONSTRUCT, CHRONPROSE). Every CHRONSTRUCT requires either DATE, DATERANGE, or DATESTRUCT. Chronology search results deliver DATERANGEs before DATEs, as a useful reminder that history consists more of processes than of events. Can be used in a CHRONSTRUCT instead of DATE, but we try to be very selective about using DATERANGE for extended periods like an entry subjectâ€™s university career, job, etc, because on the whole a start date gives a more useful result. Through use of the CERTAINTY attribute DATERANGE can define a certain span (of a journey, a lecture course etc.) or an uncertain point in a span. It contains only the text that is pertinent to expressing the range of dates at hand and should exclude all unnecessary punctuation. It has attributes CALENDAR, CERTAINTY, TO, FROM, and EXACT. The three last attributes combine to perform the same function that the VALUE attribute performs in DATE and DATESTRUCT subelements.

div.codeblock: Late in the <DATERANGE FROM="1947" TO="1949" EXACT="none">40s</DATERANGE>
<DATERANGE CERTAINTY="roughlyDated" FROM="1847-05-11" TO="1847-07-30" EXACT="none">During the voyage</DATERANGE> to the colonies, she received word that her novel was accepted for publication.

div.p: When entering DATERANGEs, follow the standard written format of standardDate1-standardDate2 (12 October 1933-23 October 1933). Such dates do not need to be standardised in the to and from attributes. When tagging a DateRange of years, please make sure you write the years numerically in full. For instance, do not write 1722-25, but 1722-1725. The following date expressions do not need to be regularized in attributes: <DATERANGE>1899-1902</DATERANGE> <DATERANGE>14 August 1742-12 March 1745</DATERANGE><DATERANGE>April 1900-June 1900</DATERANGE> <DATERANGE>1899-March 1902</DATERANGE> <DATERANGE>27 January 1645-March 1656</DATERANGE> <DATERANGE>23 May 1972-1983</DATERANGE> Any dates that are not expressed in this regular fashion will need to have a To, From, and Exact attributes filled in.
When using a broad DateRange in a chronStruct, please remember the event will be sorted according to its opening date.

The attribute Exact combines with Certainty values to indicate reliability of dates at each end of the range specified, e.g. <DATERANGE CERTAINTY="Cert" FROM="1847-05-11" TO="1847-07-30" EXACT="FROM">From mid-May to the end of July 1847</DATERANGE> This means the start date is certain; the end date is less so.
Checklist: Make sure that each date you tag conforms to the following practice checklist

ul.li: In checking, make sure format is correct: 7 January 1898 (the date can be truncated from the left but not from the right). Are there any typos? Remove any leading 0 in single-digit text dates.

If you are checking attributes, make sure format is correct: 1983-01-10, 1983-01-, 1983--. Make sure leading 0 is present for single-digit months and days. Make sure both hyphens are present. Add text to tag if it is missing (especially in chronStruct)
Where necessary, move spaces/punctuation (or add spaces) outside tag to ensure doc reads properly

Remove any BIBCIT in the tag and place them in the appropriate place remove any research notes from inside the tag and place them just outside the end tag (or delete it they are trivial and the problem has been fixed)
